title.native: はじめの一歩 THE FIGHTING!

description: Makunouchi Ippo has been bullied his entire life. Constantly running errands and being beaten up by his classmates, Ippo has always dreamed of changing himself, but never has the passion to act upon it. One day, in the midst of yet another bullying, Ippo is saved by Takamura Mamoru, who happens to be a boxer. Ippo faints from his injuries and is brought to the Kamogawa boxing gym to recover. As he regains consciousness, he is awed and amazed at his new surroundings in the gym, though lacks confidence to attempt anything. Takamura places a photo of Ippo's classmate on a punching bag and forces him to punch it. It is only then that Ippo feels something stir inside him and eventually asks Takamura to train him in boxing. Thinking that Ippo does not have what it takes, Takamura gives him a task deemed impossible and gives him a one week time limit. With a sudden desire to get stronger, for himself and his hard working mother, Ippo trains relentlessly to accomplish the task within the time limit. Thus Ippo's journey to the top of the boxing world begins.

tags.name: Boxing
tags.description: Centers around the sport of boxing.

tags.name: Primarily Male Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of male characters.

tags.name: Shounen
tags.description: Target demographic is teenage and young adult males.

tags.name: Martial Arts
tags.description: Centers around the use of traditional hand-to-hand combat.

tags.name: Coming of Age
tags.description: Centers around a character's transition from childhood to adulthood.

tags.name: Fitness
tags.description: Centers around exercise with the aim of improving physical health.

tags.name: Heterosexual
tags.description: Prominently features a romance between a man and a woman, not inherently sexual.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Delinquents
tags.description: Features characters with a notorious image and attitude, sometimes referred to as "yankees".

tags.name: Bullying
tags.description: Prominently features the use of force for intimidation, often in a school setting.

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/WANPOWANWAN)

George Morikawa is a Japanese manga author known for the long-running series Hajime no Ippo. Born in Tokyo, Morikawa was inspired to become a manga artist upon reading Tetsuya Chiba's Harris no Kaze in elementary school.

He was previously an assistant to Shuichi Shigeno, while known mangaka Kentaro Miura and Kaori Saki were past assistants to him.

Jyoji Morikawa is nicknamed and called (most of the times) George.

__Date of Birth:__ December 5, 1962

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/今堀恒雄)

Tsuneo Imahori is a Japanese guitarist and composer, and has worked with [Youko Kanno](https://anilist.co/staff/95508/) as a member of [The Seatbelts](https://anilist.co/staff/193673/).

He started to play acoustic guitar at the age of twelve, inspired by British folk music from the likes of Bert Jansch, and later the work of Frank Zappa and Andy Partridge. In 1986 he formed the band Tipographica, with saxophonist [Naruyoshi Kikuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/111335/) and jazz pianist Akira Minakami. After four albums, the group disbanded in 1996.

In 2002, after providing the soundtrack for the PS2 video game, Gungrave, the concept was subsequently developed into [an anime series](https://anilist.co/anime/267/), which's score was also handled by Imahori. In addition to scoring the anime series, he composed the music for the video game's sequel Gungrave: Overdose. He is perhaps best known in the US as the composer of several anime soundtracks, primarily [Trigun](https://anilist.co/anime/6/), [Hajime no Ippo](https://anilist.co/anime/263/) and the aforementioned Gungrave.

He has also contributed in tracks, as either a composer or a guitarist, for shows such as [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/), [Wolf's Rain](https://anilist.co/anime/202/), [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/), [NieA Under 7](https://anilist.co/anime/800/) and [Oh! My Goddess](https://anilist.co/anime/50/).

(Source: Wikipedia)

A composer and guitarist known for providing the soundtracks for [Akagi](https://anilist.co/anime/658/) and [Kaiji](https://anilist.co/anime/3002/), as well as for collaborating with [Yoshihisa Hirano](https://anilist.co/staff/102221/) for the music on [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/) and [RD Sennou Chousashitsu](https://anilist.co/anime/3363/). He also collaborated with [Kenji Kawai](https://anilist.co/staff/100304/) on [Otogizoushi](https://anilist.co/anime/525/).

Aside from his work as composer, he also plays guitar in the rockband Shocking Lemon.

In May 2012, he was arrested on marijuana charges and has been inactive since.

A composer and guitarist known for providing the soundtracks for [Akagi](https://anilist.co/anime/658/) and [Kaiji](https://anilist.co/anime/3002/), as well as for collaborating with [Yoshihisa Hirano](https://anilist.co/staff/102221/) for the music on [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/) and [RD Sennou Chousashitsu](https://anilist.co/anime/3363/). Aside from his work as composer, he also plays guitar in the rockband Shocking Lemon.

In May 2012, he was arrested on marijuana charges and has been inactive since.

A composer and guitarist known for providing the soundtracks for [Akagi](https://anilist.co/anime/658/) and [Kaiji](https://anilist.co/anime/3002/), as well as for collaborating with [Yoshihisa Hirano](https://anilist.co/staff/102221/) for the music on [Death Note](https://anilist.co/anime/1535/) and [RD Sennou Chousashitsu](https://anilist.co/anime/3363/). He also collaborated with [Kenji Kawai](https://anilist.co/staff/100304/) on [Otogizoushi](https://anilist.co/anime/525/).

Aside from his work as composer, he also plays guitar in the rockband Shocking Lemon.

In May 2012, he was arrested on marijuana charges and has been inactive since.
Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). He is a member of the Writers Guild of Japan.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/168586097)

Koike aspired to become an animator after having seeing [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s work on [Galaxy Express 999](https://anilist.co/anime/1301/). During his third year of high school Koike came to Tokyo and quickly got a job at [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/), and got thrown straight into [Yoshiaki Kawajiri](https://anilist.co/staff/100812/)'s projects. He made his debut as an in-betweener on [Phoenix: Karma Chapter](https://anilist.co/anime/2997/) and as a key animator on [Goku: Midnight Eye](https://anilist.co/anime/1879/).

His first venture into directing was in year 2000, when he got to direct the opening of Party 7, a film directed by [Katsuhito Ishii](https://anilist.co/staff/102102/). Koike also acted as the character designer and animation director on the film, getting to fully display his influences from above-mentioned legendary animator Yoshinori Kanada as well as Mike Mignola, an American comic artist of Hellboy fame.

Some time after this began the notoriously lengthy seven year production of [Redline](https://anilist.co/anime/6675/). The film was eventually released in August 2009. Despite the positive critical response, with particular praise for its animation, Redline didn't have a successful run at the box office. It did however see a much greater success after its home release and has since been recognized as a cult film.
He was an art director working for Atelier Bwca.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小島正幸) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masayuki_Kojima)

Originating from Kaname Production, currently affiliated with [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).

Known for directing shows such as [Monster](https://anilist.co/anime/19/), [Made in Abyss](https://anilist.co/anime/97986/) and [Hanada Shounen-shi](https://anilist.co/anime/2004/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小島正幸) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masayuki_Kojima)

Originating from Kaname Production, currently affiliated with [Kinema Citrus](https://anilist.co/studio/290/).

Known for directing shows such as [Monster](https://anilist.co/anime/19/), [Made in Abyss](https://anilist.co/anime/97986/) and [Hanada Shounen-shi](https://anilist.co/anime/2004/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/girodetakahashi)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/). Animates on rare occasions.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.
He passed away from undisclosed causes in January 2020.
He is an animator, character designer and animation director. He was formerly affiliated with Tama Production.
Highly praised for his mechanical drawings by [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/).
